TROPICS like it's hot! We have payload deployment!   

The science team will now seek confirmation of signal which may take several orbits. For updates on TROPICS tracking, follow

!

Liftoff! Two small satellites are on the way to join two already in orbit for our TROPICS mission. TROPICS will provide near-hourly data that could improve forecasts of tropical cyclones and severe weather.

LIVE: Watch a total solar eclipse in Australia with us! We're sharing live telescope views and answering your #AskNASA questions on NASA Science Live.

From Monday's #Artemis II crew announcement to the latest science updates from Mars and Uranus, it's been a whirlwind week across the solar system.

Check out what else has been going on This Week at NASA—then get the details on our Artemis II mission: https://nasa.gov/specials/artemis-ii/…

An epic dance: At this very moment, the #JunoMission spacecraft is approaching Jupiter for its 50th close pass of the giant planet. Ride along using our 3D solar system simulator: https://go.nasa.gov/3ZI8Q7v

Stars: always making a dramatic exit!  

Webb’s powerful infrared eye has captured never-before-seen detail of Cassiopeia A (Cas A). 11,000 light-years away, it is the remnant of a massive star that exploded about 340 years ago: https://go.nasa.gov/3ZJnk72

"Galactic winds" can spread starstuff far and wide—including elements crucial for life on Earth.

A new 
@chandraxray
 study is taking a look at the giant star clusters that cause this cosmic wind to blow: https://go.nasa.gov/40rNn3S

From space, air, and on the ground, 
@nasa
 studies Earth and the ways it is changing. These observations help us better understand – and prepare for – the effects of human-caused climate change.
 
Today we released our 2023 climate strategy. https://go.nasa.gov/40rbT5a

Travel to the Australian Outback to learn about the launch of a sounding rocket – a small rocket bringing science instruments briefly to space, studying everything from our atmosphere to the stars.

The latest episode of our Curious Universe podcast: http://go.nasa.gov/3G0K4IF

Last October, a pulse of intense radiation swept through the solar system so extraordinary that astronomers quickly dubbed it the BOAT – the brightest of all time. The source? A gamma-ray burst, the most powerful class of explosions in the universe. https://go.nasa.gov/42HrCyB
